description: Explore Canada's largest collection of original War of 1812 buildings and take part in year-round special events on this 43-acre site.. Built in 1793, Fort York National Historic Site is the birthplace of urban Toronto. It is best known as the location where the Battle of York came to its violent climax in 1813 during the War of 1812. The Fort served as the city's primary harbour defence between the 1790s and the 1880s, and was the home of a military garrison until the 1930s. Today, its defensive walls enclose Canada's largest collection of original War of 1812 buildings. Every year, thousands of people visit the site to explore its fascinating history and enjoy its public programs. Fort York is one of 10 historic sites operated by the City of Toronto. Toronto's Historic Sites engage visitors, inspire passion, challenge ideas and connect the past to the present.

reviews.title: Kitchen tour brings heat.
text: The tour was very informative. The tour guide was well versed in the subject matter.
The  woman doing the kitchen lecture, on the other hand, was chippy and rude. Took away from the whole experience.

Instead of advising us visitors of where to stand and where not to stand, she chose to wait until I stepped on the brick hearth to rebuke me with; “PLEASE DONT WALK ON THE BRICKS.” The fact that she said “please” had nothing to do with manners. She was hostile and I didn’t appreciate being spoken to like this.

In future, perhaps she could be told to politely inform visitors where they can walk, and more importantly where they are prohibited from walking, instead of waiting for a breach of her rules and then jumping on the unsuspecting offender.

reviews.title: Excellent tour with knowledgeable staff
text: My wife and I plus a friend visited from out of town and we were very impressed. Knowledgeable staff provide an excellent tour through the fort complex. So much of the original fort remains intact and well maintained. And it’s a free visit! Take advantage of it.

reviews.title: Interesting historic site
text: This is a good place to visit if you are into military history or just history in general.  I got there right before one of the free tours started.  They last about 45 minutes and you learn more about the fort and the daily life of the solders that lived there.  I spent the rest of the time walking around the buildings, some you could enter, others you couldn't.  I was there around 2 hours.  There are washrooms in the visitor center and within the fort near the shop.  It was a little confusing finding the entrance to the visitor center.  It was the 4th door down along Fort York Blvd.

reviews.title: Excellent War of 1812 Museum
text: Free to enter and with free guided tours, this is a must do for any history buff visiting Toronto. The story of Fort York is the story of the beginnings of Toronto and the museum does an excellent job preserving and displaying the most important historic site in the city. From its construction to the devastating American attack and its renewed existence after, it takes you into a world long gone that shaped Canada today.

reviews.title: Take The Guided Tour!
text: I was with family and we had a bit of time to kill so we decided to pay a visit to Fort York. Firstly it is free to visit so this is always a good thing as far as I am concerned.
We went to the visitor centre first which was really interesting as this gives you an idea of what happened leading to the invasion of the Americans to the area.

After this we went to the fort and took the guided tour. It was excellent! Really interesting and worth doing to give you an idea of what life was like in the fort for the soldiers and also the officers.
The old buildings are well preserved and it is worth having a wander around to have a look inside and see what life was like in the 1800's.
They have a well stocked gift shop as well which is worth checking out once you have finished your visit.

reviews.title: Could have been better
text: Could have been better. It was great to see this historic place in the middle of a busy city, but the site had not been well managed. Therefore, some structures were rebuilt, so it lost the originality a bit. However, it was still unique, and a great place to learn history of the region.

reviews.title: Short but informative experience
text: Took the kids (9 and 13) for a low cost morning during our recent trip to Toronto. We didn't join a tour, just walked around on our own. The 13 year old proclaimed it "boring" but the 9 year old and both adults enjoyed the walk. We thought there was just enough reading to keep you informed but not so much that it got tedious. The best part was that it was free! We were happy to introduce our American kids to another perspective on history (especially the indigenous perspective), and we appreciated how well maintained and welcoming this exhibit was. Thanks Toronto!

reviews.title: The past meets the present
text: Very interesting fort. This fort saw some of the earliest formations of Canada. During the war of 1812 verse fort took part in a number of battles. It was destroyed once. It was rebuilt and probably had a significant impact on the way Canada was formed. And the buildings in the history is still there.

reviews.title: Well worth a visit
text: Guide books don’t tell you how informative and well presented this historic site is. Thought we would spend half an hour or so but stayed 4 hours! And it was free. This gem should be well supported

reviews.title: Interesting history and free!
text: Some interesting buildings and tour guide, and all free. They provided a wheelchair as well. Worth the trip.

reviews.title: 200 yr old Toronto alive in a downtown urban setting
text: Its amazing to see such an important part of Toronto and Canadian history alive in downtown Toronto. You feel as if you have truly entered a different century. Surrounded by Toronto's condo's its now a place of serenity...except when they set off the cannons LOL

reviews.title: so interesting - beautiful architecture.  and ice skating!
text: this was one of the sweetest museums I have been to.  Incredible history of Toronto.  wonderful architecture.  And, we  noticed a public ice skating place nearby that was so charming.

reviews.title: Very unexpected historic park in the heart of the city!
text: Museum is very thoughtfully done. The staff are pleasant to interact with. The grounds are well kept and there are informational opportunities throughout the park. Costumed reenactment was a real bonus. Kudos to the volunteer regimen dressed up in woolen costumes on a hot summer afternoon!

reviews.title: Super
text: A great full day out! We loved the demonstrations and reenactments. The lemonade was beautiful and the tours were superb.
The kids learnt a lot of information and literally enjoyed the ammunition sweets from the shop.

reviews.title: History in the middle of the city
text: It was very interesting to see the early maps that show why the fort was located in its location... which is no longer on the waterfront! The self-guided tour is very nice... I enjoyed seeing the 1815 Officers Mess Kitchen (underground) that was excavated as recently as 1987! The young folks providing fife and drum selections from the era was also very well done. I Googled the address and found the visitor's center with no problems. We walked from our hotel location near the Blue Jays ballpark.

reviews.title: Historic area
text: slightly away from the Toronto central ,but not to far to walk from King street.
It is signposted you will end up on a bridge coming from King street,from where you can see most of the site,then just follow road around to the entrance .
There are toilets before you go in ,it cost's 14 dollars entrance to the site its self.
At the entrance there is a history of what happened here on the site there are whitewashed and wooden buildings,at certain times there is musket firing display.
We were't there for that, we did see a couple of guardsmen dressed in old fashioned uniforms. An hour or so is the time you would need to visit here.
I would say its more for people with an interest of history,rather than those looking for a fortified area.

reviews.title: The origins of Toronto and the burning of Washington DC
text: It may not look like much from the outside but Fort York was the reason why Toronto was established and why it became the capital of Ontario.

Though an earthwork fort (which was ideal for stopping cannonballs) it has an assortment of buildings, some dating back over two centuries, that have been turned into very nice interpretative centres (especially the larger blockhouse).

The main interpretive centre, located under the elevated highway, is home to a rather unique immersive exhibit showcasing the American attack on the Fort and town in 1813.  It is still incredible to think the destruction of this fort in 1813 was the justification for the British attack and occupation of Washington DC in 1814.
Overall a great museum to spend a few hours in.

reviews.title: Early 19th century frontier garrison in downtown Toronto
text: Today's Toronto grew up around a British frontier fort built on the northern shore of Lake Ontario in the 1790s. Originally called York, the city was renamed in 1834. Oddly enough, the garrison itself was never actually called Fort York during its original military days, picking up the name much later during the preservation movement that kept it intact as the city grew up around it.

The most dramatic incident in the fort's early history occurred during the War of 1812 when would-be foreign conquerors, i.e., American troops, bent on conquering Canada (the Canadian viewpoint) attacked the fort and surrounding community. Upon abandoning the garrison, the British troops detonated the post's magazine killing numerous Americans including general and explorer Zebulon Pike. Fearing future invasion attempts, the British rebuilt and expanded the fort, and it is this incarnation that has been preserved and is now open to visitors.

While almost all of the building contained in the present park are original, some changes have occurred over the years. Perhaps the most obvious is that the fort is no longer on the Lake Ontario shore. During the growth of Toronto, landfill efforts moved the shore to its present location to better accommodate shipping, railroads, and eventually highways. During the depression in the 1930s, the fort gained the stone walls around its periphery as part of a public works project. While these certainly look nice, the original fort never had them. More subtle changes have affected the structures within the for, e.g., the blockhouses today have ground level entrances to make them more accessible to visitors – to make them more defensible, the original entrances were on the upper level. Of course, the structures themselves have been repurposed to serve as museum galleries and interpretive reconstructions.

We decided to see all this for ourselves on a hot Sunday morning. Our first surprise came when we approached the lot to the park's visitor center. It was roped off and the staff member guarding it told us to drive around the block to another lot. When we got to this lot, the person there told us it was reserved for vendors – hmm, this is getting interesting – and told us to go to yet another lot which we found to be full. This exhausted all of the parking in the immediate vicinity, so we were left to our own devices to find street parking several blocks away. Some 30 minutes later we finally got back to the fort's grounds. As we approached, we heard a lot of loud modern music (which seemed somewhat out of place at an 18th century fort) and saw lots and lots of people (again a bit surprising for a history museum). Apparently some sort of event was booked into the grounds outside of the fort itself. To get away from the crowds, we bypassed the visitor center and went directly to the gift shop at the entrance to the garrison compound itself where we paid the $14 Canadian adult admission price.

From there, we went next door where there is a gallery which offers an overview of the fort's history through a series of information panels and a short video. We then joined a short 30 minute tour by one of the docents of the fort's architectural features – there are many such tours given during the day on a variety of subjects. We then went off on our own to tour all of the various buildings on site. As mentioned previously, some buildings like the officer's quarters and enlisted barracks have been fitted out to show the accommodations of the soldiers stationed here. Other buildings have been turned into museum galleries – some highlighting weapons, others uniforms, still others with archaeological artifacts found during various digs on the grounds, etc.

One thing that surprised us during our wanderings was the lack of staff members – at most such sites, you find costumed staff members all over the place talking about day-to-day life, answering questions, etc. In one building, we opened a door to a back chamber to find one staffer in costume reading a paperback, while in another we found a larger group munching on Subway sandwiches – but otherwise all we saw were other paying tourists.

We did find another troubling problem when we went into the restrooms on the grounds. Someone has apparently used very high concentration ammonia as a cleaner or disinfectant in the facilities. Our eyes immediately started watering and burning, and our air passages started to close up. We did our business and quickly exited, but we can imagine someone with a respiratory problem like asthma would have been at serious risk had they gone in there.

These issues aside, we still had a pretty good time learning about early Toronto and Canadian views on the War of 1812. Overall, we were here for about two hours (not counting the half an hour trying to find parking). We suggest if you want to visit that you double check to make sure that no special event is on tap as they don't seem to have a good plan for handling parking for that and still accommodate visitors to the fort itself.

reviews.title: Hard to find and underwhelming!
text: Fort York is not promoted enough on even included on the open top tour, as a family of 5 I goggled things to do in Toronto and came across Fort York, spent an hour walking around the old buildings, listening to the band play and canon being fired, a nice way to spend an hour in Toronto but not much else.

reviews.title: Living history in the middle of a modern city
text: I would first of all agree with the reviewer who said it's not easy to find-the Fort York website does give you accurate bus & streetcar information, but fails to say how to get from the stop to the Fort. What you do is look for one of the streets which are at right-angles to the streetcar route. It's Gzowski Street. If you head up there, you will see the fort site, and arrows which will show you that the entrance is further along to the left. BUT please clearer directions, Fort York!

I thought everything was very well done. the day i was there, there were lots of varied events (a good tip is to phone in advance to see what's on). There was a cannon firing, a display of arns drill, a talk and a musical interlude with a selection of old military melodies.
Take the time to explore the buildings-they all have something of interest.
My favourite was the display of some of the many items they found during an archaelogical dig-each item is explained clearly and its use clarified.
well worth a couple of hours.

reviews.title: Some Changes Noted Here
text: Has been a number of years since I visted here with a long time Scouting friend plus USA visitor of mine. Tried to get a limited parking spot as people were parking here for the CNE close by. However a Green P Parking Enforcement gave me a break in finding a spot were I did not need to pay. The entrance to this place has changed and has interactive disoplays plus a short movie of the battle here during the War of 1812. Other these notes here the fort has not changed this much over the years. Great place to learn about life in the City of York plus Canadian military history.

reviews.title: A trip back in time
text: Took a trip to Fort York, Toronto and learnt about the history of the battles between the English and the US.  Great little place for some history and something different from the main city.  The demonstration of the cannon was cool and the other reenactments are good too.

reviews.title: Good historical site
text: This old fort is tucked between rail lines and highways.  Yet you go back in time.  I learned quite a bit about the War of 1812 here.  And the cannon demonstration was a blast.

reviews.title: Slice of history - it was ok
text: Fort York is located east of the Downtown area in Toronto. It’s easily walkable from (say) Union Station - straight along Front St then follow the signs. Entry fee is $14 and inside it’s a small green area with a collection of huts - some dating back to 1812. There are also a few cannons. There is a free guided tour which was quite interesting. It was good to see the contrast of this place against the backdrop of the city - it has glass high rise buildings around it. Overall I was happy to made the effort to visit here but it’s not a “must see” (for me) and I wouldn’t visit again.

reviews.title: Learning is Life-long endeavor
text: Fort York was a strategically important military installation prior to and after the American Revolution.  Under British/Canadian and US control during this period.  During the War of 1812 (April 1813 to be exact) US forces wrested control of the Fort from the Brits, Canadians, and First Nations and used it as a base to loot and burn the growing town (including Parliament).  It was for this action that the Brits burned the US White House in August 1814.  My wife and I enjoyed the exhibits and restored encampments near the heart of Toronto.  Plan on spending at least two hours to view the Fort and exhibits.

reviews.title: Canadian History comes alive.
text: Tucked in between rail lines, and monster highways is this little piece of important Canadian history. Well preserved, well presented and worth the history lesson regarding the battle between England and the unites States.
The visitor center is bright and very informative. Fort York does not require a full day, but well worth the two hours.

reviews.title: Short history visit
text: Start at the Visitor Centre to understand the War of 1812 and the Battle of York on April 27, 1813. $14 entrance fee.

reviews.title: A Tiny Gem
text: Don't miss this special historic site near the lake, critical to learning about the roots of Canadian history. Dynamic new exhibits in the visitor center add to the classic re-enactor demonstrations. Meet the staff and volunteers to discover what makes this site so important.

reviews.title: Photo opportunity
text: Just as you go through the gift shop entrance, there are rooms on the left, in one of them there are hanging soldiers outfits, jackets and such. It is OK to put them off to take photos in them. This was the highlight of our visit.
And of course we learned a lot about the war 1812 - coming from Russia, I had no clue, there it's the 1812 war with Napoleon.

reviews.title: Good summary of Toronto's history
text: On a freezing day in sub-zero temperatues I wondered what I was doing in an outside venue, but it was bright and sunny which made the visit good. As you'd expect few people around in winter; probably more lively in summer, but at least I got to see everything without queuing. The displays, videos, pictures and exhibitions provided a good background without too much details (unless required) for a brief visit. Staff were friendly and helpful.

reviews.title: Interesting history
text: It's quite the contrast with the surrounding high-rise condos and the nearby Gardiner Expressway, but it's interesting to see the original buildings and the reconstructions.  Also interesting was the fact that this was once lakefront property, before part of the lake was filled in to create the current shoreline.

You can't beat the price (it was free!).   Weekends are the most interesting, as there  are people onsite dressed in period costume and playing various characters that would have been at Fort York (for example, someone baking scones over an open fire).

It was a bit mind-boggling to be informed that 32 soldiers would once have lived in a barracks room about 8m x 6m (25'x20'), and the contrast between how the regular soliders lived and how the officers lived was striking.
Overall, an enjoyable two hours.

reviews.title: History in our own backyard!
text: Excellent info on history and war culture from onsite experts. Well laid out site with lots of hands-on access to war memorabilia. Highly recommend it for families for learning more of Canada’s history right in our own backyard!

reviews.title: History and Origins of Toronto
text: Visited the site during a special World War One weekend when entry was made free. It was very well organised with demonstration drills, artillery exhibits and medical camps to get a peek into 19th century history and war time life. I Learnt about the origins of the city of Toronto. Would highly recommend this to everyone whether visiting or living in Toronto, to understand the history of the city. Particularly enjoyed exterior tour and the Swiss teams’ enthusiastic explanations at the Swiss exhibits.

reviews.title: A nice place to see and learn about Canadian history
text: Fort York is where Toronto began. It is a battlefield and a rare collection of original buildings set amidst the new condominiums of the modern city. A pleasant place to havea visit.

reviews.title: How Toronto Began
text: Visited with my wife who is a historian with a special interest in US history. This was a tremendous visit. The history of Toronto and Canada in general was presented in a very interesting and professional way. The original buildings were the highlight. I highly recommend this to anyone at all interested in the history of Toronto and North America in general. Excellent job.

reviews.title: If you’re American you better look at this.
text: The war of 1812 was the true war of American independence. Come find out why at the fort. War crimes happened back them too. Ask them about the powder keg.

reviews.title: Field trip with grade 7 class
text: I was a little hesitant to bring fifty 12 year olds to the Fort having not been myself, but it could not have been better organized! We got there and were immediately met by our guide, Mike. He was excellent - very engaging, a great sense of humour. There was a cute gift shop there that the students were very excited about. We also had a lunch room for them to eat, though they were free to explore the fort at this time too.
Overall, a very informative and engaging trip. We will be coming back!

reviews.title: How it all began
text: This is the place to learn about Toronto history. Perfect restorated and preserved buildings and artifacts on the actual site of the historica fort itself. In the visitorcenter there is a short movie which get you started in the history, and from the center it is a short walk to the site itself. There are hourly tours around the fort included, but the site is also pretty selfguided with the informationpanels provided. When interested in historyand specially Toronto’s (why you see everywhere the name York for instance?) this place is a must. Easily reachable with the streetcar and can spend a few hours here.

reviews.title: Excellent History
text: Restored buildings with informative exhibits.  The video at the beginning helps set the stage for the rest of the visit.  I enjoyed and learned from the weapons exhibit.  Also good information on the area.  Recommend for all ages.

reviews.title: Wonderful
text: This is a great experience. The visitor centre is a great entrance to a place that is an important piece of Toronto and Canadian history. Well worth taking the time to see.
